By P.J. Huffstutter and Tom Polansek
| CHICAGO
CHICAGO U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump named 64 agriculture policy advisors on Tuesday
column2: including the governors of Iowa and five other farm states and a former federal agriculture secretary.The announcement came as Trump
column3: a New York businessman seeking his first elected office
column4: looks to improve his standing among voters
column5: particularly those in swing states such as Iowa
column6: where some recent opinion polls show Trump and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in a tight race. Republican Governors Terry Branstad of Iowa
column10: Mary Fallin of Oklahoma and Pete Ricketts of Nebraska were included on a list of advisors distributed by Trump's campaign.Branstad spokesman Ben Hammes said in an interview that the governor will focus on increasing government support for renewable energy as part of the committee.Also on the list were John Block
column11: U.S. agriculture secretary under Republican President Ronald Reagan from 1981 to 1986
column12: and former Governors Rick Perry of Texas and Jim Gilmore of Virginia
column13: who both unsuccessfully ran against Trump for the Republican nomination.

column1: The members of my agricultural advisory committee represent the best that America can offer to help serve agricultural communities
column2: Trump said in a statement.Members of an executive board will ""convene on a regular basis
column3: he said.Committee members have already talked via telephone to outline some of the issues they expect to tackle
column4: committee member A.G. Kawamura said in an interview.

column1: They range from immigration and climate change to global trade and ""how to define food and energy security for the U.S. in the years ahead
column2: said Kawamura
column3: a former California agriculture secretary.Battles between the agriculture sector and its critics have grown fierce in recent years - from fights over water access in California and declining grain prices
column4: to mounting pressure from consumer groups over how food is produced and labeled.

column1: Both presidential campaigns have largely ignored the sector
column2: though
column3: Kawamura said
column4: adding that lack of discussion was one of the reasons he joined Trump's committee.In June
column5: representatives of about a dozen agricultural associations
column6: including the American Farm Bureau Federation and the National Farmers Union
column7: met with staffers for Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton for the first time to begin a discussion on farm policy.Clinton had a 6-percentage-point lead over Trump in a Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll released on Tuesday. (Reporting By P.J. Huffstutter and Tom Polansek; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Perry'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-briefing-idUSKCN10R25T	Trump to receive first security briefing: sources	"
By Mark Hosenball
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump is expected to receive his first national security briefing this week from intelligence officials
column2: sources said on Tuesday.Representatives from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence will give the New York businessman a wide-ranging briefing on foreign policy and national security issues and current threats
column3: but not ultra-sensitive information about ongoing U.S. undercover spy operations or the identities of intelligence sources and methods
column4: according to a source familiar with the matter.The Director of National Intelligence serves as the head of the U.S. intelligence community
column5: advising the president
column6: the National Security Council and the Homeland Security Council on matters related to national security.""I know that there will be a briefing
column7: and it will be this week
column8: Trump foreign policy adviser Walid Phares confirmed in an email to Reuters.

column1: ABC News reported that Trump will be accompanied to the briefing by two top advisers
column2: General Michael Flynn
column3: a former Defense Intelligence Agency chief
column4: and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie
column5: who heads Trump's White House transition team.A source familiar with briefing procedures said that it was unclear whether Flynn and Christie currently have the type of active security clearances that would allow them to participate in such a briefing but that they likely held them in the past.

column1: Neither Flynn nor a campaign spokeswoman immediately responded to requests for comment on the briefing.Officials have expressed some concern about whether Trump
column2: who has never held public office
column3: will be able to keep sensitive secrets he might hear to himself. Republicans have pointed out Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton
column4: when secretary of state
column5: used a personal email system to transmit allegedly sensitive government messages
column6: some of which were classified ""Top Secret"" after the fact.

column1: There was no indication on Tuesday that Clinton has thus far requested such a briefing for herself
column2: sources familiar with the briefing process told Reuters. (Reporting by Mark Hosenball; Additional writing by Amanda Becker; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Clinton'

While Trump appeared to claim credit for prodding NATO to focus more on the threat of terrorism

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-northcarolina-idUSKCN10Q29S	North Carolina asks Supreme Court to reinstate voter ID law	"

WASHINGTON North Carolina on Monday asked the U.S. Supreme Court to allow a state law requiring voters to show identification to remain in effect for the Nov. 8 U.S. election despite an appeals court decision that the measure discriminates against minority voters.Lawyers for Republican Governor Pat McCrory said the status quo should be maintained so close to the election
column2: citing court precedent in their favor. The law
column3: which also limited early voting
column4: was enacted in 2013.    The Richmond
column5: Virginia-based 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled on July 29 that the law intentionally discriminated against minority voters. The same court refused to put its decision on hold for the November election.

column1: Critics say such laws
column2: passed in Republican-governed states
column3: make voting harder for minorities such as African-Americans and Hispanics
column4: who tend to support Democrats. Backers say the laws are necessary to prevent voter fraud.

column1: The state directed its request to Chief Justice John Roberts
column2: who has responsibility for emergency requests arising from the federal appeals court that covers the state. The state is not seeking to restore all provisions of the law that were invalidated
column3: meaning some provisions will not be in effect for the election whatever the high court does.

column1: (Reporting by Lawrence Hurley; Editing by Howard Goller)"	['McCrory'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-asia-idUSKCN10R02L	Republican Asia experts say Trump presidency would be 'ruinous'	"

WASHINGTON U.S. Asia experts who served in past Republican administrations said on Monday they would back Hillary Clinton in the presidential race as a Donald Trump presidency would lead to ""ruinous marginalization"" for the United States in the region.In an open letter
column2: the eight former senior officials said that with global strategic competition growing
column3: including from China
column4: it was ""absolutely the wrong time to elect an unstable
column5: ill-prepared amateur with no vision or foresight to meet the manifold challenges of the 21st century.""They said the Republican nominee offered ""only bluster or preposterous panaceas"" for Asia that would ""wreck our country's credibility
column7: and leadership in very short order.""The signatories to the letter included Michael Green
column8: who served as President George W. Bush's top Asia adviser at the White House
column10: a former deputy assistant secretary of defense
column12: a former senior official at the U.S. Agency for International Development.Should Trump get the chance to put his ""nostrums"" into practice
column13: Asian countries would be forced to shift towards states challenging the United States
column15: and some might seek security through nuclear weapons

column1: In short
column2: if the Trump brand ... becomes America's brand
column3: we can expect ruinous marginalization in Asia and unwanted compliance with rules which the Chinese and other challengers set
column4: they said.Their letter was the latest repudiation of Trump's candidacy by Republican national security specialists.Last week
column5: 50 former Republican national security officials
column7: called Trump unqualified to lead and said he would be ""the most reckless president in American history.""

column1: Trump responded to that statement by deriding the signatories as members of ""the failed Washington elite"" who ""deserve the blame for making the world such a dangerous place.""Trump has caused alarm in Asia and beyond by saying he would consider letting Japan and South Korea build their own nuclear weapons
column2: rather than have them relying on the United States for protection against North Korea and China.

column1: While making U.S. allies anxious

column3: such as by comparing the U.S. trade deficit with China to rape. One Chinese state newspaper equated him to Hitler.At the same time
